DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said he cannot say if the US will strike a final deal with China although talks are going very well, while there were separate comments from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that he is pleased with progress on trade talks with China and expects elements of Chinese trade talks to be resolved in the near future. (Newswires/CNBC)

China and US are said to delay Trump-Xi meeting until April as according to sources, while there were later source reports that China is proposing tying in an official state visit by President Xi to a US trade deal. Separately, White House expects a significant market pop with a significant China trade deal and advisors reportedly have said the Dow could pop 2,000 points according to Fox's Gasparino. (Newswires)

US is mulling targeted sanctions related to human rights violations in China's Xinjiang region, according to the State Department. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK lawmakers voted (412 vs 202) to accept the government's motion to extend the Article 50 process beyond 29th March. Furthermore, lawmakers had rejected Amendments E (302 for vs. 318 against) which calls on PM May to seek an Article 50 extension to avoid leaving the EU on 29th March without a deal and to provide parliamentary time for the HoC to find a majority for a different approach. Parliament also rejected Amendment I which proposed Parliament force a series of indicative votes on 20/March on the next Brexit steps and rejected Amendment H (85 for vs 334 against) which would have instructed UK PM May to request an extension of Article 50 of sufficient length for a referendum to be legislated for and held with options for leaving on terms determined by parliament or staying in the EU.

UK PM May spokesperson said May has given commitment to bring forward legislative measure required to change the exit date in law. The spokesperson also stated that A50 delay would not result in a transition period extension if a deal is reached but added that the government is still preparing for no-deal and that Parliament will discuss next steps on March 25th if Brexit deal fails. (Newswires)

If UK PM asked EU for an extension to the Article 50 process, EU might not make the decision at the 21st March summit and may schedule an emergency EU summit for a few days before the 29 March exit date, according to ITV's Peston. (ITV)

BoE's Haskel warned of risks to the UK jobs market, while he emphasised a data dependent approach and wants concrete evidence of rising inflation before favouring rate hikes. (FT)

UK Liberal Democrats party leader Vince Cable will step down in May. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said guidance from the central bank prevents premature rate hike expectations and that ECB policy will depend on data. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

OPEC monthly report stated that OPEC crude production fell 221k bpd in February to average 30.55mln bpd according to secondary sources and that OPEC members bound by supply cut deal met 105% of the pledged reductions in February vs. 101% in early March. Furthermore, it stated total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.43mln bpd, down by 40k bpd from the previous estimate amid downward revisions in both OECD and non-OECD regions, while 2019 oil demand growth is forecast is maintained at around 1.24mln bpd. (Newswires)

Russia and Saudi energy delegates to meet in Baku on Sunday. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said the EU has been very tough to deal with and that if the EU doesn't talk to them, the US is going to tariff their products. Elsewhere, there were reports that the European Parliament failed to back the start of trade talks between the EU and US, while US President Trump also commented US looks forward to negotiating a 'large-scale' trade deal with the UK. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin urged members of Congress to pass the USMCA deal, while he added that he supports clean debt ceiling increase and called on Congress to raise the debt limit soon. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

General Electric (GE) opened higher today after CEO Larry Culp provided a promising outlook for the years ahead, despite 2019 being disappointing. Dollar General (DG) nosedived on the back of its earnings report which revealed a large amount of new stores to open will weigh on its bottom line. Apple (AAPL) caught a bid, helped by an “outperform” initiation at Cowen. TechnipFMC (FTI) was an outperformer whilst rumours floated it was the frontrunner for a contract from Equinor in Norway. Take-Two (TTWO) pares back Wednesday’s rally after Sony (SNE) denied speculation it was considering an acquisition. Bristol-Myers (BMY) underperformed on the back of a positive drug patent outcome for Celgene (CELG), which caused it to trade higher, making the merger deal more likely. SPX -0.09% at 2808, NDX -0.19% at 7243, DJI +0.03% at 25710.

Treasuries edged slightly lower on Thursday, with the T-plex ran into the session on a downward path where hedge funds were reported to be selling at the long-end, causing the curve to steepen. Although this was supported by CTAs covering their shorts just before the US equity open, with some block buyers in the front end, but this trend halted as Europeans began leaving their desks, keeping any price rallies limited. Going into the settlement, yields rose across the curve, long-end saw yields rose the most prolific with the 30-year up by c. 3.5bps. Spreads also widened further, where the 5s/30s at the greatest in 13 months and the 2s/30s greatest in 9 months. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5 ticks lower at 122-22+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 14 March 2019: Trump & Xi meeting delayed; UK lawmakers vote for A50 extension
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 14 March 2019: Trump & Xi meeting delayed; UK lawmakers vote for A50 extension

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities down/flat, dollar up, treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Trump & Xi meeting late April at earliest; UK lawmakers approve an extension of A50, subject to EU’s approval; US new home sales surprise fall, imports & exports prices rose; OPEC cuts world oil demand estimate

* AHEAD: BoJ Rate Decision, Italian Industrial Orders & Sales, EZ CPI (Final), US NY Fed Manufacturing, US Manufacturing Output & Industrial Production, BoJ Kuroda Speaking, ECB's Rehn Speaking, Quadruple Witching

 

* TRADE: The US and China reportedly agree to delay the meeting between US President Trump and China President Xi; the meeting, which was being planned for the 27 March, has been pushed back until at least the end of April. Both sides have indicated that are planning to arrange a meeting between the leaders at the earliest possible date, with Beijing said to be pushing for a formal state visit rather than a regular meeting. Analysts at Stratfor said that China's decision to push for an official state visit reflects Beijing's concern that a simple meeting between Trump and Xi may not produce an agreement, similar to the recent summit between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un that abruptly ended without progress. "Additional delays to a potential summit between Trump and Xi, alongside ongoing talks between both sides, increase the likelihood that the United States and China will simply extend their trade truce and postpone the signing of an actual trade deal," the geopolitical consultancy said. On trade, Trump himself said that he cannot say when a final China trade deal will be struck, and added talks were going well. On Europe, Trump was more belligerent, describing it as difficult to make progress with Europe, and threatened that if the Europeans do not want to talk, he will apply tariffs on their goods. Elsewhere, the White House reportedly expects a significant market pop with a significant China trade deal, with advisors reportedly saying that the Dow could pop 2,000 points on a deal announcement, according to Fox's Gasparino.

* BREXIT: GBP failed to sustain the no-deal driven rally yesterday and is set to close the day in the red. This comes as UK whips came back into power after yesterday’s lack of discipline, as the government got a much-needed win and passed their motion to seek an extension to Article 50 (assuming convincing justification) unamended. Whilst the fine margin of loss in amendment I saw marginal downside for cable, as the power of Brexit’s future path was not granted to the remain-leaning house, GBP completed the voting session in the green as the intent to seek an extension allows for more breathing room to negotiate and prepare for a new exit date. The cross maintains some downside risk, however, as questions remain about the length and possibility of an extension as it requires EU approval. The government’s stated intention is to look for a short, technical postponement (suggested to be June 30th) whilst the EU is looking for a longer one (21 months has been floated); as such EU rhetoric henceforth becomes much more pivotal, especially considering the suggested frustration from the EU side that PM May is holding a third vote on her deal on the eve of the EU summit.

* US NEW HOME SALES: Fell unexpectedly in January, though upward revisions to the prior painted offset (cumulative revisions saw 63k added over the last three months). Sales declined by 6.9% MM to 607k, lowest since October 2018. Month's supply picked up to 6.6, the highest since October, while median home prices fell by 3.8% YY, a decent improvement from the -7% in December, and -10.7% in November. "Overall, in spite of the weaker than expected sales in January upward revisions to Q4 2018 data and the improving trend in home prices paint a somewhat healthier picture of housing activity and a stabilization compared to the steady slowing trend during the first three quarters of 2018," Barclays said.

* IMPORT/EXPORT PRICES: US import prices rose by 0.6% MM in February, a rebound from January’s 0.5% drop - which has now been revised to a 0.1% rise - and higher than the expected 0.3% rise. However, in a YY basis “import prices remained in deflationary territory for a third straight month, down 1.3% y/y in February. Softer global growth, a stronger dollar, and lower oil prices are now pressuring domestic inflation downward. However, with imports only comprising a sixth of GDP, the pass-through is small,” Oxford Economics’ (OE) analysts comment. Supporting the figure was the rebound in energy prices going into the year, however the non-fuel components were “unchanged” or “sluggish” in February. Export prices rose by 0.6% MM too, greater than the expected 0.1% rise, with the previous 0.6% drop being narrowed to 0.1%. OE adds, “prices for both agricultural (+0.3%) and non-agricultural exports (+0.7%) added support to the headline gain. From a year ago, export prices accelerated to 0.3% y/y after briefly slipping into deflationary territory, down 0.2% y/y in January.”

* PREVIEW - BOJ: The Bank of Japan will conclude its latest 2-day policy meeting on Friday in which consensus is for the central bank to maintain NIRP at -0.10% and keep QQE with YCC unchanged in which it will purchase JGBs so that 10yr JGB yields remain around 0% with some flexibility. The BoJ is also expected to maintain forward guidance of keeping rates at current extremely low levels for an extended period of time considering the uncertainties related to the economy and prices including the impact from the scheduled sales tax hike later this year. (Click for full preview)

* WTI (J9) SETTLED USD 0.35 HIGHER AT USD 58.61/BBL, BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.32 LOWER AT USD 67.23/BBL. After oil’s rally upward earlier in the week, Thursday’s session was somewhat choppy. Demand side factors were again limiting the rally with China’s industrial output coming in softer than expected, yet again an ominous figure from the super-nation. Additionally, OPEC released its monthly report which sees total world oil demand growth in 2018 is at 1.43mln BPD, down by 40k BPD from the previous estimate amid downward revisions in both OECD and non-OECD regions. However, “OPEC production did decline 221k BPD to 30.549mln BPD during February according to the report, but this was largely in line with earlier estimates and so, market expectations,” Citigroup analysts note. The report showed that the OPEC members bound by the supply cut deal met 105% of the pledged reductions in February (in early March it was reported at 101%), which bulls will be glad to hear. Also weighing on commodity prices was a stronger dollar, in the midst of a more strained risk appetite after reports a Trump and Xi meeting wouldn’t happen till at least late April.   

* SPX -0.09% at 2808, NDX -0.19% at 7243, DJI +0.03% at 25710. SECTORS: Energy +0.06%, Materials -0.80%, Industrials -0.35%, Cons Discretionary -0.31%, Cons Staples -0.28%, Healthcare -0.25%, Financials +0.41%, Tech +0.20%, Telecoms -0.40%, Utilities -0.14%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: General Electric (GE) opened higher today after CEO Larry Culp provided a promising outlook for the years ahead, despite 2019 being disappointing. Dollar General (DG) nosedived on the back of its earnings report which revealed a large amount of new stores to open will weigh on its bottom line. Apple (AAPL) caught a bid, helped by an “outperform” initiation at Cowen. TechnipFMC (FTI) was an outperformer whilst rumours floated it was the frontrunner for a contract from Equinor in Norway. Take-Two (TTWO) pares back Wednesday’s rally after Sony (SNE) denied speculation it was considering an acquisition. Bristol-Myers (BMY) underperformed on the back of a positive drug patent outcome for Celgene (CELG), which caused it to trade higher, making the merger deal more likely.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 5 TICKS LOWER AT 122-22+. Treasuries edged slightly lower on Thursday, with the T-plex ran into the session on a downward path where hedge funds were reported to be selling at the long-end, causing the curve to steepen. Although this was supported by CTAs covering their shorts just before the US equity open, with some block buyers in the front end, but this trend halted as Europeans began leaving their desks, keeping any price rallies limited. Going into the settlement, yields rose across the curve, long-end saw yields rose the most prolific with the 30-year up by c. 3.5bps. Spreads also widened further, where the 5s/30s at the greatest in 13 months and the 2s/30s greatest in 9 months.

* JPY: The yen has remained quite resilient in the face of today's early risk-off, inspired by a weak batch of Chinese data overnight, that hit the 'risk-on' currencies, the AUD and NZD. Ahead of the BOJ's policy meeting, where the central bank is expected to dial up the dovishness, ING prefers playing the stronger USD story against the JPY. The bank notes that US data is now proving constructive, citing the durable goods report this week. Other factors remain supportive, with commodities firm, diminishing signs of a disorderly Brexit, and risk assets on the front-foot; the bank expects USDJPY to trade up to 112.20.

* GBP: GBP failed to sustain the no-deal driven rally yesterday and is set to close the day in the red. This comes as UK whips came back into power after yesterday’s lack of discipline, as the government got a much-needed win and passed their motion to seek an extension to Article 50 (assuming convincing justification) unamended. Whilst the fine margin of loss in amendment I saw marginal downside for cable, as the power of Brexit’s future path was not granted to the remain-leaning house, GBP completed the voting session in the green as the intent to seek an extension allows for more breathing room to negotiate and prepare for a new exit date. The cross maintains some downside risk, however, as questions remain about the length and possibility of an extension as it requires EU approval. The government’s stated intention is to look for a short, technical postponement (suggested to be June 30th) whilst the EU is looking for a longer one (21 months has been floated); as such EU rhetoric henceforth becomes much more pivotal, especially considering the suggested frustration from the EU side that PM May is holding a third vote on her deal on the eve of the EU summit.

* AUD, NZD: The Antipodes suffered mainly on risk-off sentiment in wake of disappointing Chinese IP data overnight that was compounded by reports of a delay for possibly another month at least for the meeting between Trump and Xi to formally seal a trade deal. AUD extended its reversal from almost 0.7100 at best to sub-0.7050 through a couple of MAs, while NZD inched closer towards 0.6800 before the Antipodean Dollars derived some traction from subsequent comments suggesting some elements of the US-China negotiations will be resolved sooner rather than later.

BREXIT ANALYSIS AHEAD OF TONIGHT’S ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION VOTE
content:
*TODAY’S VOTE: Tonight, the UK Parliament will have a free vote to extend the Article 50 process for an indeterminate period. It remains unclear how long this extension would be for (see below). However, European policymakers have been clear that there should be a convincing justification for any delay. It is likely that EU members would vote to approve any extension at next week's summit (29 March). A memo reportedly says EU is to advise that extending Article 50 only makes sense in 3 scenarios: 1) to prepare for no deal, 2) complete ratification of a deal, or 3) if the UK decides to hold an election or referendum.

 

* POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?/or beyond?

  • House Speaker Bercow proposed an Article 50 extension until June 30th
  • Shadow Chancellor McDonnell noted that the Labour party will back a limited Brexit delay
  • Chancellor Hammond highlighted that it is possible for the EU to ask for a longer extension period

 

EU SIDE

  • Reports earlier in the week noted that the EU are readying for a Brexit delay of up to one year
  • European Council President Tusk said he will appeal to the EU27 to be open to a long extension if the UK finds it necessary to rethink Brexit strategy and build consensus around it
  • Reports stated that Germany and Austria are opposed to extend Article 50 beyond the EU elections (May 23rd)
  • French President Marcon is reportedly keen to extend Article 50 by up to 21 months.
  • Portuguese Foreign Ministry is ready to support a long Article 50 extension to find a solution, and added that it needs to be longer than some weeks
  • Italy's Foreign Minister said Italy should vote in favour of an Article 50 extension
  • Reports state that the EU are angry that PM May is holding a third vote on her deal on the eve of the EU summit

 

* AMENDMENTS SELECTED FOR TODAY’S VOTE

(E) LABOUR: Instruct PM May to seek an Article 50 extension to avoid leaving the EU on 29th March without a deal and to provide parliamentary time for the HoC to find a majority for a different approach.

(H) WOLLASTON-WHITFORD-CHERRY-BRAKE: Instruct PM May to request an extension of Article 50 of sufficient length for a referendum to be legislated for and held with options for leaving on terms determined by parliament or staying in the EU. Labour said it will not be supporting this amendment.

(I) BENN/LETWIN/COOPER/GRIEVE/LAMB/HOSIE: Proposes parliament to force a series of indicative votes on March 20th on the next Brexit steps

(J) BRYANT/BRAKE/ROBERTS/WHITFORD/MCGOVERN/DOUGHTY: Orders the Government not to move a further motion asking the House to approve the Withdrawal Agreement and framework for the future partnership that the house declined to approve on 15 January 2019 and 12 March 2019.

NB 1: If amendment H passes, then amendments I or E will not be voted on; if amendment I passes then E will not be voted on. Amendment J adds to the end of the motion so the passing of the first three will not rule out J.

NB 2: The UK Government are whipping against all the amendments tonight

NB 3: Labour are to reportedly back amendment E, I and J whilst abstaining from H

NB 4: ERG say they will vote against all amendments in tonight's votes, in line with the government, but will vote as they like if the main government motion is not amended.

* SCHEDULE (UNCONFIRMED)

Around 1130 GMT (0730 EDT/ 1230 CET) - House Speaker selects amendments with debate to commence shortly after

1330 GMT (0930 EDT/ 1430 CET) - PM May Cabinet meeting

1700 GMT (1300 EDT/ 1800 CET) – Parliament to vote on amendment H

1715 GMT (1315 EDT/ 1815 CET) - Parliament to vote on amendment I

1745 GMT (1345 EDT/ 1845 CET) - Parliament to vote on amendment E

1800 GMT (1400 EDT/ 1900 CET) - Parliament to vote on amendment J

1815 GMT (1415 EDT/ 1915 CET) - Parliament to vote on the main Article 50 motion

 

* EUROPE WILL ULTIMATELY DECIDE: As things stand, if MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit becomes possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imaginations since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that will not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling unable to extend Brexit bull run ahead of A50 extension vote
content:
GBP

The Pound appears to have hit the Brexit buffers, or merely just exhausted the limits of euphoria over UK Parliament’s rejection of no deal, as the focus switches to extending the March 29 deadline and another Meaningful Vote before going back to the EU to request a delay, if that is what the HoC wants. Cable continued its retreat from 1.3300+ highs after falling just short of 1.3400, and almost hit 1.3200 before stabilising again. Note, the MPs have started debating amendments before the voting kicks off around 17.00GMT and the main motion is tabled, but for a more detailed primer and analysis please consult our headline feed.

AUD/NZD 

The next major currency losers, mainly on risk-off sentiment in wake of disappointing Chinese IP data overnight that was compounded by reports of a delay for possibly another month at least for the meeting between Trump and Xi to formally seal a trade deal. Aud/Usd extended its reversal from almost 0.7100 at best to sub-0.7050 through a couple of MAs, while Nzd/Usd inched closer towards 0.6800 before the Antipodean Dollars derived some traction from subsequent comments suggesting some elements of the US-China negotiations will be resolved sooner rather than later.

JPY

Although off worst levels within a 111.73-14 range vs the Dollar, the Jpy remains below the 200 DMA (111.43) and cautious ahead of the looming BoJ policy meeting that could culminate in a more downbeat economic assessment/outlook and cement recent dovish rhetoric via revised guidance.

USD 

Volatile trade for the Greenback and index between 96.483-821 parameters amidst fluctuating US-China headlines via the President and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, choppy moves elsewhere and eyeing several technical levels. The DXY is currently just over 96.700, with support via the 30 DMA (96.602) nearby, but not a lot in terms of resistance before 97.000.

EUR/CAD

Also on the back foot vs the Buck having lost momentum and conceded ground to the recovering Usd, with the single currency clinging on to the 1.1300 handle following a foray below in wake of another marked downgrade to German growth this year (Ifo almost halving its GDP estimate to 0.6%), and the aforementioned less constructive Washington-Beijing updates. The Loonie got to within a whisker of resistance at the 100 DMA (1.3281) before recoiling back below 1.3300 as the oil rebound stalled and Canadian house prices slipped in January.

CHF

The Franc looks set to end the EU session as the G10 outperformer or most resilient as Usd/Chf remains confined to a tight 1.0050-30 range after less deflationary Swiss data in the form of producer/import prices.

subject: OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production fell 221k bpd in February to average 30.55mln bpd, according to secondary sources
content:
• OPEC members bound by supply cut deal met 105% of the pledged reductions in February (in early March it was reported at 101%)
  • Crude oil output decreased mostly in Venezuela, Saudi Arabia and Iraq, while production inched up in Libya and Angola.
  • Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.43mln bpd, down by 40k bpd from the previous estimate amid downward revisions in both OECD and non-OECD regions.
  • For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.24mln bpd; unchanged from the prior
  • Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 30k bpd from the previous month’s report, mainly due to higher-than-expected output in Canada in Q4 2018, and is now estimated at 2.74mln bpd to average 62.19mln bpd
  • Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was also revised up by 60k bpd, due to expected production increases in Canada as of April, as well as higher-than-expected growth in the Sudans

subject: US President Trump says US looks forward to negotiating a 'large-scale' trade deal with the UK
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Trade deal sentiment rocked after US & China said to delay Trump/Xi meeting until April
  • Major European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] are firmer, but off of bests after Trump/Xi delay
  • Dollar respite as G10 counterparts falter
  • EU Council President Tusk says will appeal for a longer extension if the UK finds a delay necessary
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Import/Export Prices & Jobless Claims, HoC Vote on Extending the Brexit Negotiating Period, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin budget testimony, ECB's Lane, BoC's Wilkins Speaking

ASIA

Asian stocks were initially higher across the as the region took early impetus from the US, where sentiment was underpinned by favourable data. This saw all US major indices finish positive with the S&P 500 at a 4-month high and in turn spurred the momentum in Asia, although the risk tone was eventually clouded as participants digested Chinese data. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (U/C) both gained at the open with energy the outperformer in Australia after oil prices hit their best levels since November, while SoftBank shares were among the top gainers in the Japanese benchmark after reports it is in discussions regarding a USD 1bln investment into Uber’s self-driving unit. Chinese markets instigated a turnaround but with the downside in the Hang Seng (+0.1%) limited by notable strength seen in China’s oil majors and as China Unicom rallied post-earnings, while Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) underperformed and fell below the 3000 level following mixed data with Retail Sales inline with expectations and Industrial Production at a 17-year low. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid upside in Tokyo stocks and as the BoJ began its 2-day policy meeting, although there was a different picture in the longer-end as both 20yr and 30yr JGB yields fell to November 2016 lows.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7009 (Prev. 6.7114)

Chinese Industrial Production YTD (Feb) Y/Y 5.3% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 6.2%); weakest in 17 years. (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales YTD (Feb) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.2% (Prev. 9.0%)

US

China and US are said to delay Trump-Xi meeting until April, as according to sources. (Newswires)

US President Trump says he is prepared to veto if necessary, referencing the National Emergency vote today by the US Senate on Border Security & the Wall. (Twitter)

UK/EU            

*For reference a Brexit analysis post including potential amendments is available on the headline feed

Tory MPs will be given a free vote on a government motion for a "short technical extension" to Brexit; according to BBC's Norman Smith citing sources. (Twitter)

EU Council President Tusk says he will appeal to the EU27 to be open to a long extension if the UK finds it necessary to rethink Brexit strategy and build consensus around it. (Twitter)

UK PM May reportedly prepares a 3rd vote on the Brexit deal and is also said to warn Tory rebels to back her deal by next week or risk a long extension to Article 50. Separately, ERG’s Francois also said he would not back PM May’s deal. (Newswires/Times/Guardian)

Over 100 UK MPs have backed an amendment to today's motion on delaying Brexit to stop a people's vote from taking place; according to PoliticsHome. (PolitcsHome) While reported indicate that Brexiteer Tory MPs are lining up "in their dozens" to vote against the Government's Article 50 motion tonight, according to The Sun's Political Editor Tom Newton Dunn. (Sun)

Indications of a plan for a cross-party amendment forcing the government to hold indicative votes. Which could be a very big deal if tabled., Sky's Rigby.

UK Shadow Chancellor McDonnell says Labour will back a limited extension, adding that it is possible the EU may insist on a longer extension period. (BBC/Sky)

ERG member confirms that they were shown a new draft of Attorney General Cox's legal advice, which is built around Rees-Mogg's suggestion of using Article 62 of the Vienna Convention, which lays out how a country can unilaterally terminate an agreement., ITV's Brand. (Twitter)

GEOPOLITICAL

US plans to test-launch missiles later this year after President Trump recently pulled out of the Nuclear Force Treaty. (Newswires) US Senate voted 54-46 to end US support for the Saudi-led war in Yemen. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are in positive territory [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%] initially following the positive sentiment on Wall Street where the S&P 500 finished at a 5-month high and above the key 2800 level; although indices have fallen off sharply off of session highs following reports that the meeting between US President Trump and Chinese Premier Xi is delayed to at least April. While this has been seen as a potential outcome for a while markets were still taken by surprise hence the significant drop from session high. Sectors have strengthened throughout the session to all being firmly in the green, after a somewhat mixed start to the session for sectors; with IT names the initial notable laggard. Notable movers include K+S Group (+7.3%) at the top of the Stoxx 600 after their FY18 EBITDA beat on expectations, alongside the Co. presenting strong EBITDA guidance for 2019. At the bottom of the Stoxx 600 are Lufthansa (-5.3%) after the Co. cut its growth plans as higher fuel costs weighed on earnings. Elsewhere, RWE (+0.3%) shares have been volatile since opening lower by around 2% after the Co. posted earnings below expectations, the turnaround in shares may be due to the Co. stating that they are confident the timetable for a E.ON (-0.1%) deal can be adhered to, after highlighting a potential delay to it in the event of a hard Brexit.

FX

DXY - Some respite for the Dollar and index after Wednesday’s relatively sharp sell-off, as the steeper reversal from recent 97.000+ highs stopped at the 96.371 level that coincides with technical support on some charts. However, the rebound was at least partly if not mainly due to external factors with several major counterparts undermined bearish impulses or running out of bullish momentum in the case of Sterling. The DXY is just shy of a recovery high inches above 96.750, and the 30 DMA at 96.602 could be key in terms of a firmer rebound or fade before another leg down towards the next downside technical level ahead of 96.000, which comes in at 96.283.

AUD/NZD/GBP/JPY - It’s a 4-horse race to avoid being last G10 currency to Thursday’s (EU session) finishing post, as the Aussie is undermined by data again, albeit Chinese this time rather than domestic, and fresh reports about a delay to the eagerly awaited Trump-Xi Summit to sign off a trade pact. Aud/Usd has slipped back further from near 0.7100 at one stage to 0.7050 and the Kiwi in sympathy with Nzd/Usd now around 0.6817 vs 0.6865 at best. Meanwhile, the Pound has pulled back following another Brexit-related spurt that catapulted Cable to circa 1.3340 before a retreat through 1.3300 to 1.3250. Sterling got an extra boost from the 2nd UK Parliamentary vote this week that saw a no deal in any guise rejected by MPs, in principle at least. Attention now turns to an extension of the March 29 Article deadline, and the strong prospect of that being approved has prompted PM May to tentatively schedule a 3rd MV sometime before next week’s EU Summit. Elsewhere, Usd/Jpy has backed off from circa 111.73 overnight peaks on the aforementioned breaking US-China news, but the headline pair remains above a key chart level in the form of the 200 DMA (111.43) and could be prone to further upside if the BoJ is as dovish as expected tomorrow, or even more. Note, for a full preview of the impending policy meeting please refer to the Ransquawk Research Suite.

CHF/EUR/CAD - All holding up better against the Buck revival, as the Franc hovers close to the top of a 1.0050-30 range and perhaps finds some traction from firmer than forecast Swiss import/producer prices (albeit still deflationary in y/y terms). Meanwhile, the single currency is keeping its head above 1.1300, marginally, but shy of Fib resistance (1.1327 represents a 38.2% retracement of this year’s 1.1570-1.1177 move) after another hefty 2019 German GDP forecast downgrade (0.6% from 1.1% per Ifo) and the Loonie is back below 1.3300 vs its US rival against the backdrop of toppy oil prices and ahead of Canadian house price data then a speech from BoC’s Wilkins.

FIXED INCOME

No further, or at least not much more follow-through selling at the lows in core debt prefaced a period of consolidation, and the less positive headlines about no meeting between US President Trump and his Chinese counterpart this month also sparked a mild safe-haven bid that lifted Bunds to a marginal new Eurex session high of 164.40 (-7 ticks vs -36 ticks at worst). Meanwhile, Gilts still lag but are back near the top of the range and US Treasuries ditto. Ahead, weekly claims and import/export prices ahead of housing data plus a testimony from Mnuchin and the last of this week’s UK Parliament Brexit votes (but far from the final chapter in the long-running saga as an extension appears likely, not to mention a 3rd MV possibly next Wednesday).

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.2%) and Brent (-0.1%) futures have slipped following reports that a Trump-Xi summit may be delayed until April vs. prior expectations of an end-March summit. As such WTI and Brent futures fell back into their respective one-month long range of around USD 3.50/bbl. This summit push-back has however been touted for a while as USTR Lighthizer recently noted that sticking points remain in talks. Elsewhere, Iraqi Energy Minister emerged on the wires stating that the nation will decrease crude exports to average 3.5mln BPD from USD 3.62mln BPD in order to comply with OPEC’s output curbs. As a heads up, OPEC’s monthly oil report will be published today at 1200GMT/0800EDT. The metals market is largely on the backfoot amid a pick-up in the USD wherein the yellow metal breached USD 1300/oz to the downside. Gold is now back below its 50 DMA at 1303/oz ahead of its 100 DMA at 1271/oz. Elsewhere, copper erased its three-day gains amidst a firmer Buck couple with a turnaround in risk sentiment after the Trump-Xi meeting.

US is seeking to reduce Iran oil sales by about 20% to below 1mln bpd from May and is likely to renew sanctions waivers to Iranian oil buyers but could deny waivers to countries not using them, according to sources. (Newswires)

CME lowered COMEX 5000 silver futures margins by 8.4% to USD 3300 per contract and lowered COMEX copper futures margins by 11.1% to USD 2400 per contract. (Newswires)

Iraqi Oil Minister says the current oil price range of USD 60-65/bbl is "relatively comfortable", but the nation is seeking a higher price for crude oil than current prices. Iraq has cut oil export average to 3.5mln BPD (vs. Prev. 3.62mln). (Newswires)

subject: There is almost a hundred percent chance that appointment of Lane to ECB, Laviola to SRB, and Campa to EBA will be approved today according to EU Parliament spokesperson

If UK government gets a meaningful vote though before 20th, and EU gives a short extension, government will do as much as it can to get the law required through the Commons so we can still leave as soon as possible, BBC's Chief Political Editor

EU Council President Tusk says he will appeal to the EU27 to be open to a long extension if the UK finds it necessary to rethink Brexit strategy and build consensus around it
content: Link to Tweet
analysis_details:
This follows reports that the UK are seeking a shorter 'technical extension', with the House of Commons speaker stating the governments extension motion for today will propose an extension until 30th June. Recent comments have seen UK Chancellor Hammond state the Labour party will back a limited extension. 

From the EU's perspective, their consensus is to support either a short extension if the UK government can demonstrate an agreement being likely within such a period, otherwise support is for a longer extension of at least a year which would require the UK to participate in EU elections.

subject: Gilts cresting wtd lows, as Short Sterling futures factor in fading no deal Brexit risk
content: UK debt and STIR contracts continue to trade inversely with the Pound on unfolding Brexit developments and with 2 down and just one to go in terms of this week’s Parliament votes, the prospect of a cliff-edge climax has diminished even if that scenario remains the default withdrawal scenario if no alternative arrangement is forged and mutually approved. On that note, while an extension to the March 29 Article 50 deadline be put before the House of Commons later, albeit earlier than Tuesday and Wednesday according to reports, momentum is building behind a 3rd Meaningful vote possibly next Wednesday, just ahead of the March 21-22 EU Summit. Back to Liffe, Gilts have had a very close look at Tuesday’s 126.43 intraday low, but are now just off worst levels within a 126.77-47 range and the 3 month strip is 0.5-3.5 ticks adrift vs 0.5-5 ticks down at one stage.

Bunds: churning within a lower range ahead of EU cash bourse opens
content: The 10 German benchmark gapped down off the Eurex open to 164.21 from Wednesday’s 164.47 close and subsequently retested yesterday’s late lows, but held at the base of support in the 164.19-17 area before paring losses and recovering to 164.36, which forms the top of near term resistance on some charts. The softer tone chimes with price action in US Treasuries following a rather sluggish finale to this week’s supply as the 30 year sale tailed and failed to muster strong demand with yields at multi-month lows just above 3%. This has prompted a bit more steepening along the curve, and resurgent oil prices may also be a bearish factor at present. Back to Bunds, nearest tech levels outside the current range come in at 164.47 and 163.92, while the corresponding yield looks flanked between 0.5-0.1% awaiting clearer fundamental direction.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 14th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks were initially higher across the as the region took early impetus from the US. However, the risk tone was eventually clouded as participants digested Chinese data
  • UK Government Brexit motion to rule out a no-deal in any scenario and Brexit Amendment A were both accepted by the HoC last night
  • Focus now turns to today’s vote on potentially extending Article 50; Government extension motion proposes an extension until June 30th
  • US President Trump said he is in no rush to get a China trade deal and that it is going along very nicely
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, German & French CPI (Final), US Import/Export Prices & Jobless Claims, HoC Vote on Extending the Brexit Negotiating Period, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin budget testimony, ECB's Nowotny & Lane, BoC's Wilkins Speaking
  • Earnings: Bollore, Generali, Adobe, Oracle

14th March 2019

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks were initially higher across the as the region took early impetus from the US, where sentiment was underpinned by favourable data. This saw all US major indices finish positive with the S&P 500 at a 4-month high and in turn spurred the momentum in Asia, although the risk tone was eventually clouded as participants digested Chinese data. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) both gained at the open with energy the outperformer in Australia after oil prices hit their best levels since November, while SoftBank shares were among the top gainers in the Japanese benchmark after reports it is in discussions regarding a USD 1bln investment into Uber’s self-driving unit. Chinese markets instigated a turnaround but with the downside in the Hang Seng (Unch.) limited by notable strength seen in China’s oil majors and as China Unicom rallied post-earnings, while Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) underperformed and fell below the 3000 level following mixed data with Retail Sales inline with expectations and Industrial Production at a 17-year low. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid upside in Tokyo stocks and as the BoJ began its 2-day policy meeting, although there was a different picture in the longer-end as both 20yr and 30yr JGB yields fell to November 2016 lows.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7009 (Prev. 6.7114)

Chinese Industrial Production YTD (Feb) Y/Y 5.3% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 6.2%); weakest in 17 years. (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales YTD (Feb) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.2% (Prev. 9.0%)

US President Trump said he is in no rush to get a China trade deal and that it is going along very nicely. Trump also commented that there is a very good chance there will be a deal with China and that It does not matter whether a deal is made at or before a summit, while he added that Chinese President Xi has seen that he can walk away. (Newswires

UK/EU

UK Government Brexit motion was accepted in Parliament through votes of 321 for vs. 278 against (margin of 43) which calls on the Government to rule out a no-deal in any scenario. Brexit Amendment A was also accepted by 312 for vs. 308 (margin of 4) which rejects the UK leaving the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement and a Framework for the Future Relationship, removing any reference to the default position of a no-deal Brexit, while the “Malthouse Plan B” Amendment F was rejected by 164 for vs. 374 against (margin of 210), which ITV's Political Editor Peston suggested shows remainers are taking hold of Brexit. (Newswires) Note, four senior Tory ministers abstained from last night’s vote on the no-deal Brexit motion: Works and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd, Justice Secretary David Gauke, Business Secretary Greg Clarke and Secretary of State for Scotland David Mundell. Furthermore, middle-ranking minister Sarah Newton resigned after voting against the government. (Sky News)

UK PM May said the House has provided a clear majority against leaving without a deal and the onus is now on us in the house to find a solution, while the legal default position remains that UK will leave without a deal unless something else is agreed. PM May further commented that the options remain the same in which we could have a second referendum but that would risk no Brexit at all and that the EU has been clear this is the only deal available, while she added that without getting a consensus on a deal in the coming days there will need to be a longer extension which would require the UK to take part in EU elections. (Newswires)

UK House Speaker said Government extension motion proposes an extension until June 30th. In related news, there were earlier reports that Government Officials are making contingency plans for European Elections if Brexit is delayed according to the Guardian’s Political Correspondent, while the Telegraph reported that EU officials will tell PM May to ask for a lengthy extension to the Brexit negotiations at an EU summit next week. (Newswires/Guardian/Telegraph)

UK PM May reportedly prepares a 3rd vote on the Brexit deal and is also said to warn Tory rebels to back her deal by next week or risk a long extension to Article 50. There were also reports that some ERG MPs said they will support PM May's deal in a 3rd meaningful vote on the condition PM May resigns according to BuzzFeed’s senior political correspondent Wickham. However, ERG's Baker said we will keep voting down UK PM May's deal and ERG’s Francois also said he would not back PM May’s deal. while the PM’s office UK PM May office said PM May is not mulling resigning and that the default position remains that the UK is to leave the EU on 29 March. (Newswires/Times/Guardian)

ECB's Coeure (neutral) said TLTROs are instruments that are equal and accessible everywhere, while he added that Italy faces a challenge, particularly longer-term growth, which has nothing to do with the EU and is not a threat to the EU. (Newswires)

UK RICS Housing Survey Feb -28 vs. Exp. -24.0 (Prev. -22.0). (Newswires)        

FX

FX focus was once again on GBP which rallied by around 2% to a 9-month high on Wednesday after Parliament voted for the UK Government Brexit motion which calls on the Government to rule out a no-deal in any scenario. However, GBP/USD has significantly pulled back overnight to firmly below 1.3300 as uncertainty remains considering that motions are not legally binding and that a no-deal remains the legal default position; next up for GBP is today’s vote on a potential extension to Article 50. Elsewhere, the DXY found some much-needed reprieve from yesterday’s slip from the 97.00 level and its 4th consecutive loss, as its major counterparts traded lacklustre in which EUR/USD faded some of the prior day’s gains and with antipodeans dampened by the China data, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses remained underpinned by the positive risk appetite in Japan and amid a decline in Japanese longer-term yields. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures remained afloat after the prior day’s gains of more than 2% to above the USD 58.00/bbl and its best levels in 4 months. This was attributed to risk sentiment and inventory data as the DoE inventories report showed an unexpected drawdown in headline crude stockpiles, while analysts also noted lingering factors such as Venezuela output uncertainty and OPEC+ reductions adding to the bullish backdrop for prices. Elsewhere, gold continued to pullback marginally overnight as the greenback found mild reprieve and copper was dampened after the poor Industrial Production numbers and subsequent underperformance from its largest buyer China.

 

US is seeking to reduce Iran oil sales by about 20% to below 1mln bpd from May and is likely to renew sanctions waivers to Iranian oil buyers but could deny waivers to countries not using them, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

CME lowered COMEX 5000 silver futures margins by 8.4% to USD 3300 per contract and lowered COMEX copper futures margins by 11.1% to USD 2400 per contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US plans to test-launch missiles later this year after President Trump recently pulled out of the Nuclear Force Treaty. (Newswires) 

US Senate voted 54-46 to end US support for the Saudi-led war in Yemen. (Newswires)

 

US

Treasury futures were in the red as US traders got to their desks in the morning’s risk on sentiment but pared back losses as the session progressed. The T-plex got off on a downward path as CTAs and real money reportedly pared long positions in the front-end through the belly while the leveraged accounts weighed down the long-end. The long-end of the curve sold off going into the Treasury auction for USD 16bln of 30-yr bonds today, which saw a high yield of 3.014%, the lowest yield since July last year and tailing the WI by 0.8bps. Domestic demand was a little disappointing with directs taking a small share and dealers taking a large share, although indirects took a fair chunk too. Going into settlement, there was steepening across the curve with the front-to-long end being the most pronounced, 2s/30s widened by 1.8bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled half a tick lower at 122-27+.
